Introducing JCast: Java, Jokes, and Just Being Real

May 08, 2025 ¬∑ 3 min read

‚ÄúIt started with three developers and a microphone.‚Äù

If there‚Äôs one thing we love as devs‚Äîbesides solving problems and shipping code‚Äîit‚Äôs talking about the journey. The highs, the bugs, the coffee-fueled nights. That‚Äôs exactly why we started JCast.

JCast is a Dutch-language podcast hosted by me and two awesome colleagues, Viktor and Maarten. We‚Äôre developers with different experiences, opinions, and code habits, but we share one thing: a passion for talking tech in a way that‚Äôs real. No buzzword bingo. No sales talk. Just devs chatting about the stuff that matters (and sometimes doesn‚Äôt).

How It Started

For a long time, I had this vague dream of starting a podcast. I didn‚Äôt know when, how, or with whom ‚Äî just that I wanted to share honest conversations about being a developer today.

Then one day I casually brought it up at work. One colleague was immediately excited, another jumped in with the final push: ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs actually do this.‚Äù One brainstorm later ‚Äî language, format, name ‚Äî and JCast was born.

Our slogan is Java als startpunt, alles daarrond als speelveld (Java as a starting point, everything around it as a playground). It‚Äôs our cozy ‚Äúpraatbarak‚Äù about software development, tech, and all the messy, interesting stuff around it.

Episode 1: What Is a Professional Developer, Anyway?

This first episode was a special one. Not just because it was our debut ‚Äî but because we tackled a question that‚Äôs been quietly sitting in the minds of so many devs (ourselves included):

What does it really mean to be a ‚Äúprofessional‚Äù developer? The inspiration came from Uncle Bob‚Äôs book Clean Code, which makes a strong case for professionalism as a mindset ‚Äî not just a job title. We discussed what parts of that message resonate with us today, and where we‚Äôve started to question or reinterpret those ideas based on our own experience.

Some things we explored:

  • üí° What do we mean when we say ‚Äúprofessional‚Äù? Is it about writing tests? Is it about taking ownership? Communication?
  • üß† How do you balance idealistic principles like TDD with the messy reality of deadlines and legacy code?
  • üîç What habits have made us better devs ‚Äî and which ones do we still struggle with?
  • üí¨ When do you push for quality, and when do you just ship it?

We each brought different perspectives: some of us lean more toward principles, others toward pragmatism. But that‚Äôs what made the conversation real ‚Äî not polished takes, but honest reflections.

And yes, we made room for the doubts too. Imposter syndrome? Still there. Pressure to ‚Äúknow everything‚Äù? Big time. But naming those things out loud felt empowering.

üéß You can listen to Episode 1 on Spotify ‚Äî and we‚Äôd love to hear your take on it.

Why This Matters (To Us)

We didn‚Äôt start JCast to chase followers or become tech influencers. We started it because we craved something real. A space where developers ‚Äî from juniors to seniors ‚Äî could hear honest conversations about what it‚Äôs like to grow in this craft.

Yes, we talk about tech: Clean Architecture, UI/UX, cloud, security, testing, tooling ‚Äî the kind of topics we wrestle with every day. But we approach them the way we do with each other at work: With curiosity, nuance, and zero gatekeeping.

JCast isn‚Äôt about preaching best practices from an ivory tower. It‚Äôs about sharing the messy middle. The questions we‚Äôre still exploring. The patterns we‚Äôre still figuring out. And yeah, the things we‚Äôve messed up and learned from.

It‚Äôs about:

  • Real talk over buzzwords
  • Growth over gatekeeping
  • Questions over certainty
  • Laughter over lectures

We want JCast to be a place where learning feels natural, not forced. Where technical depth and personal growth go hand in hand. And where listeners feel like they‚Äôre not just tuning in ‚Äî they‚Äôre part of the conversation.

If you‚Äôve ever felt unsure, overwhelmed, or just excited about where tech is going ‚Äî you‚Äôre in the right place.

And yes‚Ä¶ there may be the occasional SpongeBob reference.
